meta_info.description: Configuration reference for MESA stellar wind prescriptions based on Romagnolo et al. Wind Atlas I & II and provided run_star_extras.f90.
meta_info.usage: Use this data to generate 'inlist_project' modifications for the '&controls' namelist.

repository_info.description: Instructions for generating the inlist based on the provided template.
repository_info.instruction: To fully replicate the Atlas models, use the provided 'inlist_project' file content as the BASE template. CRITICAL: Do not browse external repositories. Use the file content provided in the chat context. The MLL MUST preserve ALL existing settings in the provided 'inlist_project' (including star_job, eos, kap, and non-wind controls) EXACTLY as they appear. The MLL should ONLY modify or add the specific wind control variables defined in this JSON configuration based on the user's request.

overview.disclaimer: I am here to help you configure stellar winds following the Atlas structure. I am by no means a substitute for human-based modelling. Every other initial condition for MESA simulation is a duty of the user. Do not treat the whole stellar simulation setup as a blackbox.
overview.description: A concise summary of the available wind options and their corresponding control variables.
summary: 1. Set the initial metallicity [initial_z] and opacity metallicity [Zbase]. These should generally be kept equal.
2. Set the mass-loss recipe for optically thin winds in the high surface gravity regime (log g > 3.0) [x_character_ctrl(2)].
3. Set the mass-loss recipe for optically thin winds in the low surface gravity regime (log g <= 3.0) [x_character_ctrl(3)]. Defaults to the high gravity model if not specified.

4. Define the condition for transitioning from optically thin to thick (Wolf-Rayet) winds [x_character_ctrl(1)]. Options include 'gamma' (Eddington factor), 'eta' (wind efficiency), or 'Xsurf' (surface hydrogen).
5. Choose the wind prescription for Cool Wolf-Rayet stars (Teff < 30 kK) [x_character_ctrl(4)]. Defaults to the low gravity thin wind model if not specified.
6. Select the mass-loss model for Hydrogen-rich / Warm Wolf-Rayet stars [x_character_ctrl(5)].
7. Select the mass-loss model for Hydrogen-poor Wolf-Rayet stars [x_character_ctrl(6)].
8. Determine the condition to trigger the specific H-poor WR wind model [x_character_ctrl(10)].
9. Specify the wind model for non-Wolf-Rayet Helium stars [x_character_ctrl(9)].
10. Define the primary prescription for Cool Supergiant / Dust-driven winds (e.g., RSG/YSG) [x_character_ctrl(7)].
11. Optionally, set a secondary Cool Supergiant wind model for a different temperature range [x_character_ctrl(8)]. Defaults to the primary model if not specified.
12. Choose an LBV wind scheme if applicable [x_character_ctrl(11)].

general_logic.description: Rules for interpreting user requests and generating valid inlists.

defaults.thin_winds: If a specific thin wind model is not provided for low gravity (ctrl 3) or cool WR (ctrl 4), set them equal to the high gravity model (ctrl 2). Logic: x_character_ctrl(4) = x_character_ctrl(3) = x_character_ctrl(2).
defaults.cool_supergiant_winds: If a secondary cool wind switch (ctrl 8) is not specified, set it equal to the primary cool wind model (ctrl 7). Logic: x_character_ctrl(8) = x_character_ctrl(7).
defaults.initial_metallicity: If initial metallicity [initial_z] and metallicity [Zbase] are not explicitly requested to be different, then set the same value for both
defaults.he_stars: if no model is provided for he stars (ctrl 9), set it by default to P25

low_metallicity.condition: If initial_z <= 0.1 * Zsolar OR Zbase <= 0.1 * Zsolar
low_metallicity.message: WARNING: You have chosen a metallicity <= 0.1 Zsolar. Many mass-loss formulations are past their physical regime of validity here. For higher metallicities, iron is the driver of winds, and models were calibrated accordingly. Below this threshold, CNO becomes the major driver (see Krticka et al. 2025: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2508.21702).

xshootu_mixing.message: NOTE: XShootU V (Martins et al. 2024) confirms that rotational mixing appears more efficient at lower metallicities, with nitrogen enrichment occurring at higher surface gravities in the SMC compared to the Galaxy.

xshootu_vinf.message: NOTE: XShootU III (Hawcroft et al. 2024) finds an empirical scaling of terminal wind speed v_inf ~ Z^0.22, which is steeper than the canonical theoretical prediction of Z^0.13 (Leitherer et al. 1992).

xshootu_bistability.message: NOTE: XShootU IX (Verhamme et al. 2024) and XIII (Alkousa et al. 2025) find no evidence for a bi-stability jump in mass-loss rates for LMC B supergiants, contradicting Vink et al. (2001) predictions in this regime.

mesa_controls_definitions.description: Mapping of physical wind regimes to MESA control variables defined in run_star_extras.f90

use_other_wind.description: Must be set to .true. to activate the run_star_extras.f90 wind module.

initial_z.description: Initial metallicity of the star. Standard MESA control in &controls.

Zbase.description: Metallicity used for opacity tables. Standard MESA control in &kap.

x_character_ctrl(1).description: Transition condition to optically thick (Wolf-Rayet) winds.
x_character_ctrl(1).comments: The calculation of the eta and eta_trans factors depend on the terminal velocity adopted. Under the vinf_type variable in run_star_extras, one can modify which terminal velocity fits are used

x_character_ctrl(2).description: Optically thin winds for high surface gravity (log g > 3.0).

x_character_ctrl(3).description: Optically thin winds for low surface gravity (log g <= 3.0). Defaults to x_character_ctrl(2) if not specified.

x_character_ctrl(4).description: Winds for Cool Wolf-Rayet stars (Teff < x_ctrl(5) kK). Defaults to x_character_ctrl(3) (and thus ctrl(2)) if not specified.

x_character_ctrl(5).description: Winds for H-rich / Warm Wolf-Rayet stars.

x_character_ctrl(8).description: Secondary Cool Supergiant winds (optional). Defaults to x_character_ctrl(7) if not specified.

x_character_ctrl(10).description: Condition to trigger H-poor WR winds.

x_character_ctrl(11).description: LBV wind scheme (e.g., 'Bk10'). Active if x_logical_ctrl(6) is true.

x_logical_ctrl(1).description: If true, stop simulation when center Oxygen mass fraction drops below x_ctrl(1).

x_logical_ctrl(2).description: If true, use thin winds (ctrl 4) for Cool WR stars. If false, use thick winds (ctrl 5).

x_logical_ctrl(3).description: If true, use dedicated H-poor WR winds model (ctrl 6). If false, use H-rich model (ctrl 5).

x_logical_ctrl(4).description: Enable interpolation for optically thick wind transition. Highlight with a warning that this was not tested

x_logical_ctrl(5).description: Enable interpolation for cool supergiant wind transition.

x_logical_ctrl(6).description: Enable LBV winds beyond the Humphreys-Davidson limit.

x_logical_ctrl(7).description: Smooths transition to weaker winds following Pauli+ (2026)

x_logical_ctrl(8).description: Sticky winds: if enabled, once the star develops thick winds, it cannot go back to thin winds even if the thick winds condition is not anymore valid.

x_ctrl(1).description: Center Oxygen mass fraction limit for stopping simulation (usually 1d-4).

x_ctrl(2).description: Gamma_e transition threshold for optically thick winds (usually 0.5).

x_ctrl(3).description: Threshold value for H-poor WR transition (usually 1d-7 for Xsurf or 1d5 for Teff).

x_ctrl(4).description: Delta window for thick winds interpolation (e.g., 0.05).

x_ctrl(5).description: Temperature threshold [kK] for Cool WR winds (usually 30).

x_ctrl(7).description: Temperature threshold [K] to initiate Cool Supergiant winds. Standard values: < 8000 K for Yellow Supergiants (YSG), < 4000 K for Red Supergiants (RSG).

x_ctrl(8).description: Temperature threshold [K] for secondary Cool Supergiant wind switch.

x_ctrl(9).description: Zsolar scaling factor for mass loss rates. See 'solar_metallicity_options' for canonical values.

solar_metallicity_options.description: Canonical options for the Solar metallicity reference value (Zsolar) to be used in x_ctrl(9).

wr_classifications.description: Classification of Wolf-Rayet stars based on surface composition as defined in Wind Atlas I (Section 3.2).

types.description: Hydrogen-free (In the Atlas, as well as in Romagnolo et al. (2024) and Gormaz-Matamala et al. (2025) we set Xsurf < 10^-7) and C/O rich stars. So-called 'canonical WR'

available_mass_loss_options.description: Valid string values for wind recipes based on run_star_extras.f90.

optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: Solar (0.014) and LMC (0.006). Mass: 9-200 Msun. Hydrodynamic, includes rotation. Suitable for MS and WNh.
optically_thin_winds.warning: It is a CAK-derived mass loss, and should only be used at high surface gravity levels

optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: Solar, LMC (0.5 Zsol), SMC (0.2 Zsol). Teff: 15-50 kK. Lum: 4.5-6.0 logL. Dynamically consistent. No bi-stability jump found.
optically_thin_winds.warning: XShootU VI (Backs et al. 2024) finds SMC O-giants have rates lower than V01, aligning with Bj23. However, XShootU IV (Sander et al. 2024) suggests Bj23 rates may be too low for LMC O-supergiants unless very strong clumping is assumed.

optically_thin_winds.note: Standard OB mass loss (Eq. 1.1 in paper). Includes metallicity scaling (+0.85 logZ) adapted from Vink & de Koter (2005).
optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: CHB stars prior to LBV phase. Formula: log Mdot = 1.67 log L - 1.55 log Teff - 8.29 .
1/30, 1/10, 1/3, 1, 3, 10 Zsolar. Mass: 20, 40, 60 Msun grid. No clumping.
optically_thin_winds.warning: XShootU XIII (Alkousa et al. 2025) and IX (Verhamme et al. 2024) find NO evidence for a bi-stability jump in mass-loss rates for LMC B supergiants. XShootU VII (Bernini-Peron et al. 2024) confirms a jump in v_inf but not Mdot for SMC B supergiants.
optically_thin_winds.warning_2: The Vink & Graefener (2012) model-independent study supporting this mass loss at the transition between optically thin and thick winds was based on a small sample (~20 stars in Arches cluster) and only checked the mass loss for their current features (i.e. a snapshot), not the evolutionary history. Pauli et al. (2025) find significantly lower empirical rates for transition stars.
optically_thin_winds.note_2: XShootU IV (Sander et al. 2024) finds empirical rates for LMC O-supergiants consistent with V01 ONLY if clumping is moderate (f_cl < 5). Stronger clumping implies lower rates.

optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: 10^-2 to 1 Zsolar. Mass: 2-60 Msun stripped He stars. Fixed Teff=50kK. No clumping.
optically_thin_winds.note_2: XShootU VIII (Ramachandran et al. 2024) confirms the existence of stripped stars (quasi-WR) that do not look like classical WRs, supporting the need for specific He-star recipes.

optically_thin_winds.note: Theoretical: warn that this should be used only above roughly 0.2Zsun, includes bistability jump
optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: LMC, SMC. B-supergiants (10-28 kK). Global wind models. Finds smooth bi-stability transition (not sharp jump).
optically_thin_winds.warning: This should be used only above roughly 0.2Zsun
optically_thin_winds.warning_2: Existence and effective temperature initiation of bistability jump were not observationally verified

optically_thin_winds.note: Theoretical: includes bistability jump near Zsolar, but not at low metallicities
optically_thin_winds.note_2: For self-consistency, vinf_type should be set to 'Kritcka25' to properly calculate terminal velocities
optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: From Zsolar to 0.01 Zsolar. 10 to 45 kK. OB stars. Finds steepening of Z-dependence (alpha > 1) for Z <= 0.1 Zsolar due to CNO driving.
optically_thin_winds.warning: This should be used only at Z <= Zsun
optically_thin_winds.warning_2: Originally, when extrapolated beyond the effective temperature parameter space it can heavily underestimate mass loss (from personal experience of the dev Amedeo Romagnolo when testing it at Zsun). Clamping to the extremes is applied to avoid for underestimation.
optically_thin_winds.warning_3: Existence and effective temperature initiation of bistability jump were not observationally verified
optically_thin_winds.url: The more detailed fits for this mass-loss recipe come from the Zenodo link https://zenodo.org/records/15965163

optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Solar metallicity. Mass: 20, 30, 60 Msun O-stars. No clumping.
optically_thin_winds.warning: Existence and effective temperature initiation of both bistability jumps were not observationally verified

optically_thin_winds.note_2: Thin winds, He stars, and thick winds
optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: Galaxy, LMC, SMC. Mass: 15-150 Msun. Accounts for microclumping (D=10).
optically_thin_winds.warning: The authors highlight that their sample did not contain many Wolf-Rayet binaries, and their mass loss for this regime might be biased. This recipe scales with Iron abundance, not total Z, but in the current implementation it was changed to scale with Z/Zsun.

optically_thin_winds.note: Theoretical. Function of Teff and Mass (not Luminosity). Only valid for Very Massive Stars. Predicts two bistability jumps. This formulation is only Teff and mass dependent, and not luminosity dependent.
optically_thin_winds.note_2: Predicts two bistability jumps (Fe IV -> Fe III ~25kK, Fe III -> Fe II ~15kK).
optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: Solar (Z=0.02). Mass: 40-135 Msun. Luminosity: fixed at logL=6.0. Teff: 12-50 kK.
optically_thin_winds.warning: Limited parameter space with no luminosity and metallicity variations.
optically_thin_winds.warning_2: Existence and effective temperature initiation of both bistability jumps were not observationally verified

optically_thin_winds.parameter_space: Implicitly Galactic (Solar). Wide mass/luminosity range. No clumping (pre-dates major clumping consensus).
optically_thin_winds.z_solar_calibration: No Zsolar dependency, but it usually given a metallicity dependency from Vink & de Koeter (2005) with Zsolar = 0.019

cool_supergiant_winds.parameter_space: Galactic (Solar). T_eff 3000-4000 K for cool stars. Based on sample of 271 stars.

cool_supergiant_winds.note: RSG mass loss based on Jura (1987) / Reid (1990) for LMC RSGs (Eq. 1.2 in paper).
cool_supergiant_winds.parameter_space: Derived for LMC RSGs with M_bol < -7. Implementation uses: log Mdot = 0.8 log L - 8.7.
cool_supergiant_winds.warning: Implementation does NOT scale with metallicity. The paper suggests Galactic rates might be ~1.6x higher than this LMC-based formula. However, recent papers like Antoniadis et al. (2025) disagree

cool_supergiant_winds.parameter_space: LMC (0.5 Zsolar). Dust-enshrouded AGBs and RSGs. Teff < 3500 K (down to ~2500 K).
Galactic & LMC. M_ini 9-25 Msun. Luminosity: logL=4.2-5.6. Steady-state wind. Correction to Beasor+2020.
cool_supergiant_winds.warning: Extrapolations above 25 solar masses for initial mass leads to severe underestimations (see Atlas I). Authors claim quiescent winds cannot strip envelopes.

cool_supergiant_winds.parameter_space: SMC (0.2 Zsolar). Teff ~3300-4400 K. Luminosity: logL=4.0-5.5. SED fitting.
LMC. Teff ~3400-4500 K. Luminosity: logL=4.0-5.5. M_ini ~8-30 Msun. SED fitting with DUSTY.
cool_supergiant_winds.warning: Extrapolations to YSG (Teff > 4 kK) may lead to severe underestimations (see Atlas I). Antoniadis et al. (2025) further find NO clear metallicity dependence in the mass-loss rates between MW, LMC, SMC and NGC 6822.

cool_supergiant_winds.parameter_space: Galactic, LMC, SMC. Teff ~3200-3800 K. Luminosity: logL=4.5-5.8. M_ini ~25 Msun. Gas mass-loss rates from CO lines.
cool_supergiant_winds.warning: Extrapolations above 25 solar masses for initial mass leads to severe underestimations (see Atlas I). Suggests eruptive mass loss is needed for stripping.

optically_thick_WR_winds.note: Mass-dependent WR mass loss (derived from Eq. 11/14 in paper). Includes metallicity scaling (+0.85 logZ).
optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Wolf-Rayet stars (WNE, WC, WO). Formula: log Mdot = 2.5 log M - 7.1.
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: The original paper derives the exponent alpha=2.5.

optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Galactic WN stars. Includes clumping corrections. Standard empirical recipe.

optically_thick_WR_winds.note: Generic WR mass loss (Eq. 1.3 in paper). Includes metallicity scaling (+0.85 logZ) from Vink & de Koeter (2005).
optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Defined for Hydrogen-deficient CHeB stars with log L >= 4.5 and Teff >= 30 kK. Formula: log Mdot = log L - 10.
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: Simple relation dependent primarily on Luminosity. Does not distinguish between WN/WC types dynamically.

optically_thick_WR_winds.note: Canonical empirical. Provides generic WR formula, plus specific WN and WC formulae. Depends on surface Y and Z directly (not just scaled to solar). Z_solar calibrated with Z/X=0.0244 (Grevesse et al. 1996).
optically_thick_WR_winds.note_2: Usually MESA uses the generic WR formula by default in its Dutch winds. GENEC and Atlas I Dutch winds use the dedicated WN and WC formulae with Eldridge & Vink (2006) recalibration
optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Galactic WN and WC stars. Often used with Eldridge & Vink (2006) recalibration for WC/WO metallicity scaling. Nugis & Lamers (2002) support the high rates, arguing for deep-seated critical points.
WN and WC stars. Theoretical/Empirical compilation.
WNL stars (Late-type N-rich). Grid covers range of masses. Metallicities: Galaxy, LMC, SMC. Finds M ~ Z^0.86. Includes clumping.

optically_thick_WR_winds.note: Theoretical. Requires 'eta' transition. Sabhahit et al. (2023) recommends to use V01 without the temperature-dependent terms as the baseline for the transition check.
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: Most used formulation from Sabhahit et al. (2023) (as well as the Atlas one) scales with Luminosity (L) and Mass (M), but the physics is Gamma-driven. It essentially multiplies the transition mass-loss rate by scaling factors (Gamma/Gamma_trans)^p. This makes the rate extremely sensitive to the star's previous mass-loss history, as the current Gamma (and thus the scaling factor) depends on the current L/M ratio. Additionally, it is model-dependent because it relies on the V01 recipe to define the transition point.
Pauli et al. (2025) do NOT find evidence for the predicted 'kink' (sudden mass-loss increase) at this transition.
optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Very Massive Stars (up to 300 Msun). Transition WNh stars. Monte Carlo radiative transfer.
Metallicity: MW, LMC, IC1613. 21 WC/WO stars. Luminosity: 4.9-6.1 logL. Surface He: 0.14-0.98. Surface Fe: 0.15-1 solar
optically_thick_WR_winds.note_2: Finds weaker dependence on luminosity (0.85) and abundance (0.44) compared to NL00. Recommended for late core-He burning and post-He burning stages.
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: For hydrogen-free WC/WO stars (Y >= 0.98), a steeper metallicity dependence (~1.3) should be applied (see TSK16 Eq 3).

optically_thick_WR_winds.note: Empirical/Theoretical hybrid. He stars/SN Ib/Ic progenitors.
optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Pure He stars. Z_init: 0.02 and 0.01. Initial Mass: 4-25 Msun.
optically_thick_WR_winds.note_2: Combines Potsdam WNE data from Hamann et al. (2006) and Hainich et al. (2014) with TSK16 for WC/WO. Suggests an overall scaling factor f_WR = 1 (1.58) for clumping factor D=4 (10) to reproduce faint WC/WO stars observed in the Galaxy and LMC.
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: The bimodal distribution of helium mass (m_He ~1.0 or ~0.2) distinguishes SN Ib vs Ic progenitors. Crucial for ejecta mass predictions.

optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Galactic WC/WO stars. Hydrodynamically consistent grid.
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: There is currently no option to make these mass-loss rates dependent on metallicity in general. This is due to the fact that S19 is as a function of the Fe56 abundance not weighted by its solar value. It is therefore difficult to make a 1:1 change from Fe56 to Z

optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: LMC single WN stars. Comprehensive empirical analysis.

WNh (hydrogen-rich WR stars). Very massive stars (> 100 Msun). LMC metallicity (0.5 Zsolar). No explicit Z-dependence in B20, but Brands et al. (2022) suggest scaling with Z^0.85 (with Asplund Zsolar).

optically_thick_WR_winds.note: Theoretical. WC/WO stars. T-dependent correction from Sander et al. (2023) commented in the Atlas run_star_extras file and therefore not included by default, but it can be activated manually!
optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: WC/WO stars. Metallicity down to 10^-4 Zsolar. Luminosity: 4.8-6.5 logL. Finds breakdown of simple Z-scaling at very low Z. Sander et al. (2023) introduced a T-dependent correction (T* at tau=20, not Teff) for these rates.
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: Pauli et al. (2025) showed that SV20 mass-loss rates were too high compared to empirical findings. For metallicities below 0.1%Zsun it could overestimate mass loss by orders of magnitude (from personal tests).

optically_thick_WR_winds.note_2: Thin winds, He stars, and thick winds
optically_thick_WR_winds.parameter_space: Metallicity: Galaxy, LMC, SMC. Mass: 15-150 Msun. Accounts for microclumping (D=10).
optically_thick_WR_winds.warning: The authors highlight that their sample did not contain many Wolf-Rayet binaries, and their mass loss for this regime might be biased. This recipe scales with Iron abundance, not total Z, but in the current implementation it was changed to scale with Z/Zsun.

H00.note: Analytic evolution formulae. LBV-like mass loss.
H00.note_2: The minimum logL for the HD limit can be changed with the s% x_ctrl(6) variable
H00.parameter_space: General LBV behavior initiated at HD limit. Not self-consistent with internal evolution. Acts as additive factor to wind-driven mass loss.
H00.warning: Not self-consistent with stellar structure; triggered solely by crossing HD limit. Original limit was logL = 6.0, now set to 5.5 (Davies+18/McDonald+22).

Bk10.note: The minimum logL for the HD limit can be changed with the s% x_ctrl(6) variable
Bk10.parameter_space: Calibration predates GW detections and modern BH surveys; factor f_lbv may need re-calibration.
Bk10.warning: Not self-consistent with stellar structure; triggered solely by crossing HD limit. Original limit was logL = 6.0, now set to 5.5 (Davies+18/McDonald+22).
Bk10.warning_2: Fixed, flat mass-loss rate accounting for wind + shell ejections.

Ch24.parameter_space: Identifies opacity peaks causing super-Eddington luminosities.
Ch24.warning: Recent prescription that overlaps with the physics of inflation.

P26.note_2: Proposed as an alternative to Ch24 to better distinguish between static inflation and actual eruptive mass loss events near the Eddington limit.
P26.parameter_space: Massive star populations in LMC/SMC. Models mass ejections at Eddington limit. Additive/multiplicative factor.
P26.warning: Phenomenological model. Assumes super-Eddington layers drive mass loss rather than envelope inflation. Heavily dependent on the calibrated efficiency factor (f_ej) and assumes the HD limit is shaped primarily by these winds.

atlas_recipes.description: Prescriptions to replicate models from Wind Atlas I & II. Apply these settings to the &controls namelist.

WTW.description: Weak Thin Winds (WTW) model from Atlas I. Combines GM23 for high gravity and V01 for low gravity.
WTW.user_warning: WARNING: the eta_trans value is calculated dynamically at each timestep, not like they did in the original formulation at ZAMS.

Dutch.user_warning: WARNING: The use of this condition to thick winds will only capture post-cool supergiant Wolf-Rayet stars. You will not able to catch H-rich Wolf-Rayet or non-Wolf-Rayet helium stars!

Dutch-ish.description: Modified Dutch scheme with GM23 for high surface gravity and EV06/NL00 for H-poor.
Dutch-ish.user_warning: WARNING: The use of this condition to thick winds will only capture post-cool supergiant Wolf-Rayet stars. You will not able to catch H-rich Wolf-Rayet or non-Wolf-Rayet helium stars!

Slavic.description: Based on Krticka et al. (2024). Clumped thin winds with bistability jump and combination of multiple transition conditions to thick winds
Slavic.user_warning: WARNING: this model from the Atlas II paper, which is not yet public and finalized. Use it at your own risk

FESc.user_warning: WARNING: this model from the Atlas II paper, which is not yet public and finalized. Use it at your own risk

FESc_RSG.description: FESc model but restricts dust-driven winds to RSG phase (T < 4kK).
FESc_RSG.user_warning: WARNING: this model from the Atlas II paper, which is not yet public and finalized. Use it at your own risk

MSc.user_warning: WARNING: this model from the Atlas II paper, which is not yet public and finalized. Use it at your own risk

German_gamma.description: Uses Pauli et al. (2025) for thin winds. No bistability jump detected. Called this way because everything is dependent on Gamma_e and most formulations come from papers that are German-led
German_gamma.user_warning: WARNING: this model from the Atlas II paper, which is not yet public and finalized. Use it at your own risk

SWG.description: Strong Winds Gamma (SWG) model from Atlas I.

MS23.description: Approximation of Sabhahit et al. (2023) using V11 and Eta transition. MS23 from Atlas I
MS23.user_warning: WARNING: the eta_trans value is calculated dynamically at each timestep, not like they did in the original formulation at ZAMS.

Xsurf.description: Standard Xsurf transition model using GM23/V01 thin winds.
Xsurf.user_warning: WARNING: The use of this condition to thick winds will only capture post-cool supergiant Wolf-Rayet stars. You will not able to catch H-rich Wolf-Rayet or non-Wolf-Rayet helium stars!
